data.statement: On Adam Savage‚Äôs Tested, build/case-study videos that explicitly frame the story around mistakes or being wrong in the title (e.g., ‚Äúmistake,‚Äù ‚Äúwrong,‚Äù ‚ÄúI messed up,‚Äù plus a specific count like ‚Äútwo mistakes‚Äù) achieve 3x+ TPS by creating a strong curiosity gap and relatability compared to straightforward build titles.
data.reasoning: This video‚Äôs title leverages self-critique (‚ÄúHas Two Mistakes!‚Äù) and specificity (a concrete number) to generate curiosity about what went wrong and how it was resolved. For this channel, many titles are straightforward (e.g., object or technique focus). A deviation that foregrounds failure taps into a powerful narrative arc (setup ‚Üí error ‚Üí fix) that increases CTR and retention: viewers click to identify the mistakes and stay to see the resolution. The case-study format is well-suited to this arc, and Adam‚Äôs credibility makes the vulnerability feel instructive rather than clickbait. This pattern is testable by comparing TPS of titles containing failure/mistake language (mistake, wrong, failed, messed up, fix) and those with explicit counts (one/two/three mistakes) against the channel‚Äôs typical build titles without such framing.
